Author: beejiu
Content: In the UK for example, when you buy cigarettes you pay 77% tax. The total tax receipts for this tax are about £9bn per year, whereas the NHS spends only £2.7bn. (Figures from http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/7654153.stm, 2008.) Therefore, you could argue that the costs of this behaviour are fully funded. The point is, there are other ways to deter dangerous acts than via insurance premiums.

Author: nickpsecurity
Content:
I had an idea a while back for a HIDS or at least post-infection analysis. You record incoming data and files onto storage. Have a separate machine running it which is instrumented to check all jumps, etc against a whitelist generated when compiling same system. It would eventually spot the compromise plus be able to show the exact sequence of data & instructions that caused it. Which would aid patching it.

Stayed on prevention instead. Thought it would be fun building & optimizing it, though.

Author: PieterH
Content:
Citations, please. I've grown up and lived in many cultures. Manners change. Abuse does not. Invoking cultural relativism is not going to work here.

Let me explain: abuse is about identifying a boundary and then crossing it, deliberately, and repeatedly, to gain control over another person.

The boundaries shift from person to person and culture to culture. Yet it always the same dynamic, and you can see it, and you can stop it.

Author: gglitch
Content: I've found keeping a diary to be more difficult and more rewarding than it might popularly be thought to be. There are different approaches, from logs of events to records of thoughts/feelings, with varying levels of detail, and there are inspiring published diaries of all stripes to take as an example. I completely agree with the author about the latent connections between diarizing, privacy, self-awareness, awareness of one's public image, and the internet era. I think it'd be a great idea if diaries were a standard unit in secondary lit classwork.

Author: mark_l_watson
Content:
Great article +1 to The Guardian which is becoming a favorite source of things to read.

Good point at the end about privacy not really being about hiding dark secrets. Privacy is a psychological benefit. I argue that privacy is a basic human right.

Re: writing diaries: I sort of do this, but in the cloud. I write a ton of stuff for just myself in the form of organized notes. For things that should not be public, like research on medical problems, I like to keep notes in SpiderOak (encrypted cloud storage). For other things that are for myself but not sensitive tools like OneNote and Keep are fine.

Author: digi_owl
Content:
One example of this is the Toyota Just-in-time system, where i believe they have a number of suppliers, some of them mom and pop producers in a basement or loft somewhere, that are gathered up and delivered to the factory as needed.

And i think you find a structure somewhat similar on Germany as well, where quite a bit of the parts manufacturing is done by smaller companies dotted around the nation.

As for traditional economic textbooks being wrong by ignorance, no surprises there. Check out Steve Keen's book on the topic, Debunking Economics.

Also, as best i can tell the soviet system was pretty much a perversion of what Marx was musing about back in the day. I think he even told Lenin that the latter was barking up the wrong tree.

Author: nickpsecurity
Content:
There's a ton of COBOL doing most backend stuff. Guess it's a great language. See the problem with your claim?

Far as powerful, most things you need a new compiler for in other languages you can do in LISP with a mere library. And concisely, easily, fast, and sometimes with zero overhead. That property doesn't go both ways. Hence, why LISP is the most powerful or nearly so.

Author: peter303
Content: Disney's evolution of Tomorrowland/EPCOT reflect the three phases of futurism since Asimov's essay. In the early 20th century the future was about more fantastic machines- rockets, super-cars, better home appliance. The Tomorrowland Rocket to Mars ride embodied this. But young people became disenchanted with the pollution and militarism of hard engineering in the 1960s and turned their attention to the biological sciences on Earth Day 1970. The future was about ecology, sustainable living, commune type socialization, etc. The EPCOT dome ride embodied this vision of the future. Then came personal computers, video games, special effects movies, the internet and mobile. The future shifted to an information rich world. Now younsee lots of computer screen exhibits in Tomorrowland.

Author: kuschku
Content:
Roads for busses are far more expensive to maintain than light rail. Road maintenance of asphalt road for heavy use (like bus lanes) is so expensive that all the bus stations here are using the same road-building techniques the romans already used, and they still go through the stones in a few decades.

Just for my city the estimated savings are in the amount of 19 million EUR for switching the main bus lines to light rail.

And it would improve quality.

Author: cbd1984
Content:
> Yet what constitutes abuse is universal, and what constitutes positive social interaction is universal.

Only if you define it down to the basics. Some jokes are considered abusive in one culture and funny, or at least innocuous, in another. You mentioned one man putting his hand on another man's shoulder, but back-slapping is certainly viewed differently across cultures, and then there are the subtle rules around eye contact which usually aren't written anywhere at all except maybe sociological research papers. All of those things can make someone feel rather uncomfortable if they meet exactly the wrong person, perhaps after everyone's had a few drinks.

Abuse is culturally dependent. Some things are regarded as universally wrong, perhaps, but vast swathes of things aren't universal in the slightest.

Author: PieterH
Content:
If it's used to intimidate and isolate, then yes.

Remember school bullies? Same thing yet more subtle and stealthy.

Often the model of harassment is indirect. For instance you have a group of people who are happy and working together. A predator arrives and sees opportunity. He sees another guy is protecting and coaching the group. So he slowly undermines and destroys this guy's credibility, provoking him to anger and finally making him leave. Then, the group is exposed and easy to play with.

You almost never see it. Even when it happens to you, you can almost not see it. It is so slow, careful, smooth. This is why education of these patterns of stalking, isolation, and attack are so important.

Content:
I thought the CFAA, like the UK equivalent Computer Misuse Act 1990, governed unauthorised access to computer systems and data. Seems appropriate to me.

Paper files would probably be locked up - the equivalent prosecution would then be something like trespass, breaking and entering, or what have you.

If you have access to data for operational purposes then access outside of operational needs is just unauthorised access which on computer systems is an offence in itself because physical access is already historically covered under various laws.

Author: vlehto
Content:
That is only partially true.

Company has to be within acceptable commute range for the employee. Lets say our company needs several employees. It is necessary to have critical mass of employable people living inside that range. The problem here is that 15min commute vs. 45min commute doesn't matter much to the employer.

So companies try to go near major traffic routes at the outskirts of big cities. There employable population and cheap property converges.

Author: PieterH
Content:
Here's a funny thing about culture. It distorts a lot, so some cultures accept public stonings and lashings, while others won't let a parent slap a child.

Yet what constitutes abuse is universal, and what constitutes positive social interaction is universal. In every culture in the world, a man putting his hand on another's shoulder is a gesture of dominance, and putting his hand inside a woman's knee is a gesture of intimacy.

The size of personal spaces changes per culture. Just as some cultures speak louder than others. Yet it always follows the same dynamics, positive and negative.

Author: aninhumer
Content:
>If you believe the act of dropping a piece of paper into a box actually affects what a politician can do, I've got a bridge to sell you.

The power of democracy is that it becomes completely socially unacceptable to ignore what those pieces of paper say.

And indeed the people you're complaining about don't ignore them. They find ways to get what they want despite the system, but they never outright defy it. No one installs themself in office without winning an election (EDIT: In the US), and if anyone ever did there would be rioting in the streets.

>> I just object to libertarians pretending they can avoid it

>In fact, I've avoided all non-governmental forms of coercion all my life!

I mean that you're pretending your ideology can avoid all coercion, while ignoring the coercion involved in enforcing property rights.

Author: bfeist
Content:
I made it in these steps: - OCR data - Create timeline in premiere, time media to orig transcript (36 8-hour videos) - clean data by watching premiere by reading along OCRed data - Sync data with youtube playback via JS - create navigation scheme using paper.js - build data lazy loader in JS - collect photography, treat photography, time photography to timeline - ask my good friend, Chris to make it look nice for me

The whole site is client-side. The entire mission is loaded into the browser upon start. There's no server-side. Ironic given that my roots are as a server-side dev.

It took me years. I blogged about the making of here if you're interested: http://benfeist.com/category/apollo/

Content:
Lamenting that people need to commute for their jobs doesn't really change or help anything. People work within their systems of incentives.

Driverless cars will be an enormous help in many ways, even to traffic congestion.

Having many small buses are a distinct possibility. They could be basically boxes filled with standing people with the motors and batteries underneath. They could be be much more granular and recharge on their own. They could even turn their wheels selectively to get around smaller spaces. Even a small one could hold 6-8 standing people.

You have to realize that there is a lot more to an advancement like this then just 'now you can take your hands off the wheel'

Author: yummyfajitas
Content:
If private insurance can account for your risky behavior (as the article is describing, then no. Private insurance doesn't have this problem. And again, high deductibles mitigate it, since your risky behavior can cause you to lose 20% of your income, but still protect you from tail risk.

Why would I care that other people are having accidents or smoking?

Because you are paying for the consequences of their actions. A quick google search suggests more than 20% of the (far more than $100/month) Americans pay is caused by gluttony alone: http://www.healthycommunitieshealthyfuture.org/learn-the-fac...

That's about 1/3 of what we spent on our overpriced military. And that ignores the costs inflicted by overweight but not obese people as well as various other unhealthy behaviors.

In a country where medical professionals have no other options and therefore take low salaries, this may be less of an issue. But in the US medicine is very expensive, so it costs us a lot.

Author: cbd1984
Content:
And you have to take into account the fact culture plays a role.

What's your personal space? It varies based on where you were born and where you grew up. Invading someone's personal space is perceived as aggressive and noisome and perhaps even threatening, which makes it even worse to assume it must be based on pathology rather than "This person was born in Italy, I'm from Norway" or similar.

Similarly, saying things like "culture doesn't excuse bigotry" is rather pointless, given that culture defines what you consider to be bigotry in the first place. What's perfectly tolerant and open-minded in Russia might be unspeakable in Liberia and vice-versa.

My point is, add a culture out of step with the mainstream notions of propriety to someone with even a relatively mild social dysfunction (not necessarily diagnosable!) and you have a "harasser" in the making, especially if everyone castigates them on the first offense and nobody tells them what they're actually doing wrong.

Author: Shivetya
Content:
Trains, Trains, Trains.

Get real. First off they cost so much more per mile they already bust the bank and then comes maintenance. Finally the end is they cannot respond to population movements.

Light rail is already a boondoggle of an expense in many cities trying to fit them in, with per passenger costs so many times that of alternate solutions only a politician could love it.

Trains are a romanticism that blinds people to their real cost. Heavy rail has many uses and sharing tracks can be a good solution. However when new heavy rail is proposed they don't want to take into account existing support infrastructure, they want to build all new end points; here is a hint start and end at an major airport where taxis and buses already provide service and parking is plenty

As for the safety canard, we don't have enough history on autonomous cars and buses with proper planning to make that call. If you want to even the playing field, instead of making a new train track you instead use that same space for dedicate autonomous vehicle travel. In this you can let cars and buses serve the same central points and at the end of the route there is no need to change vehicles. Bonus, no trains or tracks to maintain!

Author: michaelsbradley
Content:
From the paper you linked to:

"Mummy semi-solid material is extracted from seams in caves and contains a composition of hydrocarbons, oxygen, nitrogen and sulphur. These materials are used as wound dressings... Some researchers combine known materials, such as bitumen chemical and spectral analysis, to indicate the presence of hydrocarbons. Two types of mummy: fat-soluble and organic materials, such as alcohol chloroform (localised type) and water soluble (type of food), have been characterised."

I may have misunderstood something, but I don't think the "mummy" of the paper is the same thing as the "mummies" of the post to which HN links.

Author: vinceguidry
Content:
When I was at RubyConf Colombia, I listened to a presenter stating that she will never again speak at or attend a conference that doesn't have an acceptable code of conduct. The reason she gave is that without a strongly-worded statement, the needs of vulnerable inevitably get trampled on, by that very antagonism the idea dredges up.

When there's not a code of conduct and available avenues for reporting harassment and, more importantly, for others to recognize when someone is getting harassed and come to their assistance, then when there is a legitimate instance, the person getting harassed always ends up getting harassed more, by the very people they're trying to go to to resolve the situation. A code of conduct makes everything clear.

Just the very suggestion that harassment could occur causes some people to really get their hackles up, as if you just accused them of harassment. I think that's the ultimate reason people have strong reactions to insistence on the need to have a policy. "Why would we need a policy, I would never harass anybody!" That sentiment itself, expressed to someone with legitimate needs, is perceived as harassment.

Author: braythwayt
Content:
I don’t know about other jurisdictions, but in Canada there is actually a law in place that allows the receiver of a payment to refuse more than a certain amount of the payment in coins.

A quick googling turns up this Wikipedia page:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_tender

The net-net is that an armoured truck full of coins is not necessarily “legal tender” in every country.

Author: aninhumer
Content:
No one asks people in your society if they agree to a system of property, you just lock them up if they try to use resources they don't "own".

And calling them "rights" instead of "laws" doesn't make following them voluntary.

Author: PieterH
Content:
The reason I wrote this article is because I think the mainstream is so wrong it hurts. All the behaviors you listed are a normal and necessary part of socialization. Without some argument there is no learning. There is a real right to freedom of speech.

This is why I tried to define "violation" from first principles as an unwanted intrusion into personal time and space. There must be (profoundly) the intention of damage. Offense is not damage.

Author: Amezarak
Content:
> What is the "content discovery" thing they are refocusing on?

Perhaps it includes things like the changes to the AwesomeBar they're making? It now (in beta) appears to prefer doing searches and visiting the root of a domain over your bookmarks and history. For example, instead of visiting the local Transmission instance hosted on my NAS when I type "transmission" into the location bar, it wants to "transmission - search with {your default search engine}.

(It also gives much weirder suggestions presumably based on the domain name - if I only type "trans" it suggests I visit "translate.google.com", a site I have visited twice in two years, vice the previous behavior, my transmission local instance. So no matter what I do, I have to hit tab twice instead of once.)

For me, this behavior is extremely annoying and disrupts my entire location-bar-typing-experience, but by suggesting web searches, perhaps it's meant to encourage content discovery.

Author: gambiting
Content:
>>The problem with this is that it creates moral hazard. There are lots of individual acts which are fun that I might engage in (e.g., gluttony, gay sex, inactivity, smoking, drugs) but which impose potential costs on others. Why is it reasonable for me to enjoy these benefits while others pay the costs?

Does it not work the exact same way with private insurance? If you require treatment, you increase premiums for everyone, not just yourself.

Anyway, I'm personally super happy with national insurance because I simply don't have to think about it. I know that if I need an operation, I will get one. I know that if I have an accident, and they need to send a helicopter to get me, I won't even see the bill for that. If I need to stay in hospital for the next year of my life, I won't see the bill. If I lose my job and become homeless I'm still going to be covered. I don't need to worry which hospital to go to, or which doctor/dentist can see me - they all can, there's no receipt produced, it's simply not a worry I have. Right now I pay about ~$100USD a month for the national health insurance, and it's an amount I am extremely happy to pay. Why would I care that other people are having accidents or smoking?

Author: PieterH
Content:
Most harassment at tech conferences is male-on-male, and it is not sexual. It is about power and control, and perhaps amusement. Sex, gender, height, choice of programming language: these are ways to create and exploit vulnerability.

Sometimes I don't think psychopaths, sorry, bad actors, care about sex at all, except as a tool for controlling people.

Author: IBMContainerGuy
Content:
Hi hmottestad!

I am one of the people working on the IBM container service that's available as part of Bluemix. I am not here in any official capacity, just as someone who wants to understand what the pain points of our customers.

Let me start by saying that I understand your pain. As every product on the market, we have issues occasionally, such as the authentication one you mentioned or the networking. However, these are only exceptions and rarely affect our users, at least as far as we are aware. Did this happen repeatedly or was it a one time occurrence?

With regards to the ticketing system, I believe you are correct. Things are not as smooth as you or I would like them to be. I will pass this on to the management chain.

For the uploading speed of images, I also believe this may be quite rare, since I cannot remember hearing complaints about it. Did this happen on separate occasions?

With that being said, please send us tickets when something is not going the way you'd expect.

Thank you for your feedback!

Author: Lio
Content:
It's a matter of perspective though.

BT was ready to roll out fibre to the home back in the early 1990s for the delivery of TV. At the time BT had some of the most advanced fibre tech in the world.

The government of the day, however, decided to ban BT selling TV in favour of opening up the market to foreign owned cable companies, Telewest and NTL.

Without wide scpread Internet use that killed the investment case for fibre (and the U.K. fibre industry).

Today we're at a situation where none of the other players calling for BT's break up want to invest nationwide.

If they do break up BT it'll be great if you're in London, Manchester, Birmingham, Leeds but I don't expect much to improve anywhere else.

I think it's more likely that Vodaphone, Sky, Talk Talk will just try milk the existing infrastructure without further significant investment, as they currently do, and BT would be dis-incentivised from further investment.

Author: KenoFischer
Content: There isn't really a good notion of the size of an elementary particle. What's really being looked for is particles with certain higher (mass) energies. Now, why do we say that higher energies allow us to probe smaller scales? Well, at small scales(/short times), quantum mechanics allows these higher energy particles to play a role, even if there's not enough energy to create an actual particle. The smaller the scale, the more do high energy particles come into the picture. Thus cranking up the energy allows us to see these particles at a larger (detectable) scale than they would usually occur.

Author: jordigh
Content:
Do you have a better explanation for the antagonism many feel (and I
  personally used to feel) towards codes of conduct?
I think there's a varying range of situations in which people feel attacked by codes of conduct.

1) People actually want the right to be an asshole. They have come to believe that everyone should be allowed to say anything they want in any situation. They call this freedom of speech. Since a Code of Conduct contradicts this expectation, they blame the CoC because it is telling them to change themselves. Nobody likes to change themself.

2) People want to have a strict and narrow definition of what to do and what not to do. In our HN-like group, people want codes of conduct to be like programming languages for humans. Since CoCs must necessarily be vague because it's impossible to narrowly codify all human interaction, people feel unsure and fearful. They thus blame the problem on CoCs and would rather prefer anarchy and being allowed to act however they wish, without fear.

3) People feel like "their" "community" is being encroached upon by foreign individuals who feel "needlessly" victimised. An analogy of the most common case, the boys' locker room is now being opened up to everyone, particularly women. Since they cannot openly attack the newcomers, instead they attack their perceived work of authorship: the code of conduct.

Author: SgtBrutalisk
Content:
This is my experience with Firefox, there will be no sources provided.

I remember using Firefox since I was in college in 2004 and I can tell you what happened when I first tried Firefox 4. The performance was horrible for a very simple reason: the system requirements were increased _tenfold_ and it was pretty much impossible to enjoy browsing using it on older hardware.

Extensions started breaking and the menu options would suddenly change place, function or disappear altogether without any prior warning or explanation. Meanwhile, Mozilla devs would either ignore the feedback or post snickering comments on their blogs.

The constant version change made it so things were rapidly falling apart - you could no longer rely on Firefox to stay one and the same for any period of time.

I saw that Firefox was going downhill, but it was still far superior to all browsers simply due to the wealth of extensions it had. And now, what is the most recent change to Firefox paradigm? Locking the extension ecosystem inside a walled garden.

I currently use Palemoon and I look forward to Edge, which promises a basically open-source environment, which will include extensions. Now that´s irony.

The term is there, I'll change it if anyone has a better one.

Edit: in my experience, the same motives that drive people to be bad actors makes them poor, even toxic, at collaboration.

Author: pornel
Content:
> Harrasement is not a gender issue

It's interesting that it can be true, but not change much in practice due to gender imbalance at tech conferences.

Let's assume that 1% of attendees (of any gender) are bad actors attacking the other gender. If a conference has e.g. 800 men and 200 women, then there will be 2 female harassers vs 800 men, and 8 male harassers vs 200 women. That's a 16 times difference in likelihood of being harassed ((8/200) / (2/800)), just from attendee imbalance, and no fault of any gender.

Author: yummyfajitas
Content:
The problem with this is that it creates moral hazard. There are lots of individual acts which are fun that I might engage in (e.g., gluttony, gay sex, inactivity, smoking, drugs) but which impose potential costs on others. Why is it reasonable for me to enjoy these benefits while others pay the costs?

One way to mitigate this would be with Singapore-style high deductible insurance - subsidies only kick in after you've spent 10-20% of your income on medicine.

See also "too big to fail", federally subsidized flood insurance, student loan guarantees, etc, all of which have the same problem.

Author: chippy
Content:
>Most of us congregate to learn and open our minds.

>A small percentage come to prey on others.

I think you would agree that here you are excluding the majority ("most of us") from a minority (a small percentage") of predators.

> This is just how it is, no good or bad.

This is thus a contradiction. You state that most people are good and some people are bad.

I would suggest that there is indeed "no good or bad" but that it not "just how it is". Rather the same people who contribute, have worth, and are open to learning and collaborating may also have the bad behaviours.

Author: vinceguidry
Content:
You're seeing the justice process work as intended. The CFAA is absolutely the wrong statute to be prosecuting his crime under. But we need actual, real-world cases to highlight these discrepancies. Now legislators can come up with a law that covers the specific case of government workers abusing the tools of state for their personal ends. Perhaps it already existed, that means the prosecutors screwed up and charged him under the wrong statute. Now they know the limits of that law and so will use the right law next time.

It's tempting to want a perfect judicial code, but it's impossible, iterated law is really the only way.

Author: chippy
Content:
This is a good approach to severe acts of harassment in real life meetings of people. In particular social events involving beer.

But these acts are rare in tech events. The most common acts of behaviour we see that some people call for Codes of Conduct are not this severe. The most common types of things would include: telling lewd jokes, being loud and argumentative, questioning particular religious or political beliefs, or being not politically correct enough.

In short behaviours which do not fall into a right and wrong objective morality, but which depend greatly on the thoughts and feelings of those offended. They are subjective. These are the behaviours which I think many proponents of Codes of Conduct in tech events are thinking of.

Author: jakobegger
Content:
This brings back memories of my first website. I hosted it on my white iBook G3, and I used dyndns to get a free hostname for my dynamic IP. The website was only accessible when I was at home, and plugged in (we had no Wifi yet).

It was pretty popular with my classmates for some time -- there was a self-written forum on it where you could upload photos, and people used it to share holiday pictures (this was before Facebook allowed everyone to share stuff online)

Unfortunately at some point the HD crashed and I lost the database since I had no backup of it -- I just didn't know where MySQL stored its files.

Author: PieterH
Content:
Feeling safe and learning aren't exclusive.

The term "bad actor" is widely accepted and understood. If you have a better term, I'm all ears. The term is accurate when seen from the perspective of the majority, which is the perspective I'm taking in this article.

As for my authority, no, all I can say is I've studied this dynamic in depth for many years and have a lot of good data on it, and tools that work. You're free to use those tools, ignore them, etc.

And it's not a pathology. It is something far more profound than that. If you're interested, and perhaps you are, read just the first chapter of that book (the PDF is free to download).
